comments.commentBody: Jen, Despite what the author of this article defines as "quirky" behaviors - eating peanut butter out of the jar is not one of them. If you meet someone who objects to any of the things you've stated here that you do alone, don't mate with them!

Funny article.  I have only been divorced for a year and I have already developed so many of these habits I sometimes wonder if I can ever live with someone again!  I have been eating peanut butter from the jar, spending too much time online, peeing with the door open, not wearing pants, singing loudly, and going to bed whenever I want to.  Maybe I will change in a couple of years, but for now, I really, really like being single and doing what I want.
Sleep too much and to do what i like and want, only. It's very good!

Did a man write this article?  A once every 7 years colonoscopy is not more uncomfortable than having your breasts squeezed between two plate every year.  The sedation is actually quite pleasant, although take the day off of work. The problem is really not if people should have it, but that so many can't afford to do.  I don't know if I'd be up for chemo and radiation if I got cancer but this prevention stuff--this I can do.

Parents - those convinced that their child must have intellectual stimulation and must be "ready" (whatever that means) - are in part behind this craze of pushing children before they are developmentally ready for certain tasks.  I always felt like I was fighting a battle when I spoke with other parents at my son's preschool, parents who were harping on about academics and "getting ahead".  Four-year-olds don't need academics, they need to play and run and discover and grow.  My son's teachers admitted they felt pressured by the parents, and in turn by the administration, to "prove" their worth by assigning homework.  I certainly wished that the parents I knew had some of that "unconditional acceptance of schools' authority", because it sure seemed like parents, school boards, administrators, the public, were steering the ship.  Those who know our kids, work with them daily, have studied child development and psychology - in short, the TEACHERS - are given very little agency anymore.

Rein it in, John

;)

you sound like a lot of fun! I love # 6!

btw, I too love making full meals for myself....gourmet ones... I mean, why the hell not? I get alot of pleasure out of preparing a meal, plating it. Heck, as many of my friends know, I've been known to make a beautiful dish for myself, and then I post a photo of it on FB so my friends can see what I'm having for dinner. And I'll even arrange the food and the plate just so, so that the photo comes out as attractive as possible. ;-)

Oh, I loved living alone. It was the result of financial independence, my vault into the middle class - earnng the national average yearly salary...Things are different now. I actually do adapt to people very well, growing up in a large family that lived in a small house. So what were my quirky habits kiving alone?

1) Practicing tango songs - reciting the lyrics in Spanish, translating them aloud into English, chanting them in Spanish, listening to interpretations over and over again. Praticing gestures to go with the songs, or dance moves that might work...

2) Dancing with my shadow

3) Taking three hours to bathe, groom, and dress myself on my days off.

4) Frying sausages after 2:00 am after a night out dancing.

5) reading out loud to myself.

6) Putting on scads of perfume at bedtime just to enjoy the scent without disturbing anyone else...

7) And though it seems normal to me, compared to the other solitaries mentioned in the article, I liked making full dinners for myself, and didn;t mind of the whole place smelled like olive oil, or fish, or steak or tuna or hard-boiled eggs or coffee...

Looking forward to earning enough to live alone again.

All hail, solteras!

Then, again, bucketomeat, perhaps not. Quantitative research using random sampling might give evidence that Lawrence Walker hasn't committed a sweeping generalization.

(I chose to live along years ago; I am a reader (don't own a tv, don't listen to radio or watch movies) and thinker. If I do say so, myself.)

The results of such research would be interesting. But maybe not of much value to anyone.
While I don't believe that all "partnered and living together" are unimaginative or that the "living alones" are uber-imaginative, I do like the term "imaginator".

Wow. So only people who live alone make hobbies of reading, crafting, inventing, and thinking? Good to know. Now I can throw out all my books, yarn, needles, thread, fabric, and chairs not facing a TV...

As Katherine Hepburn said (and I paraphrase), 'marriage would be fine as long as you were neighbors and just visited now and then.' ... I've lived alone the last 14 years, and I'd have to say nothing breeds freedom like it. freedom of action AND freedom of thought. Living alone is better for thinkers than non-thinkers. Non-thinkers subsist on gossip and tangles of social relationships, near and dear or, as is so often the case, near and not-so-dear. People who actively choose living alone are readers, crafters, inventors, thinkers and (coining a phrase?)... imaginators. By comparison, partnerships (and heavens, marriages!) often seem like failures of the imagination!

The figures still aren't convincing.  To remove pre-cancerous growth which was identified during the colonoscopies is not proof that real malignant cancer would have occured later on (although that certainly would have been possible).  The unknown variable that could have reduced malignant cancer by some 50% could also have been the positive outcome of a drastic change in food (basically more veggies and less pork).  In Southern Europe (France, Italy, Spain, Portugal) there are less such malignant tumors than in Northern Europe (Germany, Netherlands, Scandinavia, UK) becuase of different eating habits.  Also in countries like Saudi Arabia a much lower percentage of stomach tumors because of high consumption of Camel Milk (higher cleansing level of stomach, etc. compared to cow milk).  Such variables in eating/drinking habits should be part of the equation before forcing the indeed very unpleacent colonoscopy and the then following surgeries of pre-cancerous polyps.

I have a strong paternal family side colon cancer genetic risk.  Also, because of a history of bouts of, and related surgeries for diverticulosis and abdominal adhesions development, altogether I must have undergone, literally, nearly over 10 colonoscopies over the last 25 years.  I need to have them every 3 years.  Increasingly in recent years, the days-before dreaded "prep" had been mitigated, so that we are no longer required to drink those giant gallons of spit-consistency fluid tasting like swimming pool water.  Gatorade and smaller amounts of stuff.  Stressful thing is having to stop certain meds and fiber supplements in days leading up.  Other than that, this procedure is usually one of the easiest to get through -- just ask for the sedative!  And it's over like that.  Two procedures, i.e., 6 years ago, I had 3 very precancerous small polyps found -- they were removed and biopsied as benign, and in my latest procedure 3 years back, they found none.  Crossing my fingers for my upcoming next one, this summer, at age 49!  For the relatively small inconveniences and discomfort, this is SO very worth it and common sense to have this, if you're recommended to need it.
Not Groovy, Yap, but all preferable to O'Bama, you must admit Gail.
Not groovy at all, but fortunately, we got you, Gail. Dig?

The simulation didn't stop for all the families. I had to stop them after 250 kids. I am sorry to have not mentioned this. So in a way, the 2.87 is an underestimate of the actual gender ratio and you are right that it will approach 3 when you don't force a stop. In which case, it will be the best strategy if the maximum gender ratio is 75%/25% or 3 as assumed.

but when it opened a branch down the road in Westport, it only lasted a few months, killed off by many competitors, in particular Bombay Club. The many Indian restaurants in Fairfield Co, CT are more like the non-glamorous ones covered in the NYT in London - more like neighborhood cafes than the upscale and up priced ones. So while the Thali mini chain is good, it is not that differentiated. The Coromandel chain tends to be mild and so Westernized that it serves beef curry!
Wonderful biryani, Indian as well as Tibetan dishes.

In the SF area, if you want great South Indian food, head to the reliably spicy, flavorful and packed HSB (Hotel Saravana Bhavan - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saravana_Bhavan) in Sunnyvale. It's a chain, but so what?! The food is fantastic and authentic, attested to nearly all-South Asian patrons.

In West LA, the best Indian Food hands-down is at All India Café (Santa Monica and Bundy). This is the original Bombay Café of Los Angeles lore. Great punjabi food, chaat, and amazing tandoori. The best Indian lunch buffet out there.

Happy eating!
What about Paris? Any ideas????
Ajanta in Berkeley, CA, consistently wins awards for best Indian food in the Bay Area.
Ashoka the Great in San Diego. Exquisite in every way.

There has been serious change in the last 10 years - but very little when it comes to alleviating the lives of the bottom 30% t0 50% - which has multiplied in numbers at levels that evoke Malthusian concerns. Half of India's population is less than 25 years old; all were born even after the government's overt attempts to educate (and often force) people to not have too many kids. Reproduction is about the only thing within the control of half of Indians - and boy do they exercise that right.

More spending is unlikely to help. Currently, about 80% of all government spending goes into graft and corruption. The government collects all kinds of money from sales and production taxes, and then shares it with a few, close knit community of politicians, their supplicants, and industrialists. After that, it is a government dedicated to keeping people poor, disaffected, illiterate, and miserable. Prices of apartments in Bombay rival those in NY City, in a country that produces about one 25th the wealth per capita as the US. Well, a handful of people have all the money.

There are no solutions here except shock therapy. The market must become completely open, the government regulations must be eliminated, and the vast bureaucracy that exists to suck the life out of people should be eliminated - immediately. Too many low lever government employees have the power to stop economic activity, and expect a bribe. It wont solve the problem entirely, but it will help.
There is a place, Paratha Junction, specializing in Parathas  of all types in Jersey City, NJ.  It's on Newark Avenue in the Indian section of the street. Google for the website. Open 24 hrs.

You're referring to the Malabar Paratha, which is a Keralite specialty. I haven't found it in NYC yet, but you should try out the South Indian restaurants on Lexington Ave in Murray Hill. Saravana Bhavan or Anjappar, though I can't find it on their menus online. If you ever visit the SF/San Jose Bay Area, CA, you'll find it in Spice Hut in Fremont or Sunnyvale.

You can get this in the freezer section of most Indian grocery stores. Look for Kerala Parotta or Malabar Parotta (or spelled Paratha sometimes). Heat it up in a flat griddle and eat with any curry.

Very few restaurants in the US specialize in Kerala cusine. One of them is Heritage India in Houston, TX and they do have Kerala Parotta

Malaysian restaurants have a very similar concept called Roti Prata which is pretty good too.

When I went to India, the local bread in Kerala was amazing. There was no special name, just Kerala paratha. It was round and flat, and kind of mashed together out of a spiral of dough. It was softer and sweeter than most Indian breads and not particularly buttery or greasy. I've looked around for it in NYC and NJ, even going to restaurants that specialized in southern cuisine and asking around, but I haven't been able to find it here. If anyone knows what I'm talking about and where to find it, that would be amazing. (I am in Honduras now but moving back to NYC soon.)
Jersey City NJ - right near Journal Square. While they're not fancy, they cater to new immigrants and are cheap and delicious. I'm surprised that well known cluster didn't make any lists.
Heart beats for the child...shame to humanity...India needs to be take over by military now..otherwise current democratic process will never give the solution
Swagath on  the west side of Michigan State University in Eastb Lansing, Michigan is pretty good with its Hyderabadi meat dishes and South Indian doasas and idlis.
Really? That's the point you are making here?

If you notice the color is white and not black, if you may have seen today, The Wednesday, Feb 22, 2012.
Is it that the influence of Shiva on the local Catholics.
Rang Mahal in Bangkok...fantastic!
Every person worth his / her salt should be ashamed of witnessing such photos. Indian Netas and Babus should hang this photo in their bed room and see if they could sleep.
